definition:
Let $X$ be a metric space with a metric $d$. If $A$ is a non-empty
subset of $X$ and $x\in X$, then the *distance from $x$ to $A$*
[@kelley] is defined as $$d(x,A) := \inf_{a\in A} d(x,a).$$ We also
write $d(x,A)=d(A,x)$.

Suppose that $x,y$ are points in $X$, and $A\subset X$ is non-empty.
Then we have the following triangle inequality $$\begin{aligned}
d(x,A) &=& \inf_{a\in A} d(x,a) \\
        &\le& d(x,y) + \inf_{a\in A} d(y,a) \\
        &=& d(x,y) + d(y,A).\end{aligned}$$

If $X$ is only a pseudo-metric space, then the above definition and
triangle-inequality also hold.

[9]{} J.L. Kelley, *General Topology*, D. van Nostrand Company, Inc.,
1955.
